subject: RE: [junit] Logging tests reports
msgSnippet: To throw another one in the pile, Test Mentor - Java Edition (www.javatesting.com) logs test results in a XML files, including fine grained execution timing
messageBody:
To throw another one in the pile, Test Mentor - Java Edition
(www.javatesting.com) logs test results in a XML files, including fine
grained execution timing and method coverage metrics. It also has a browser
that lets you load files for past results to show differences between them,
and includes a pluggable interface for doing your own logging.

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The object testing company
http://www.silvermark.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chris Eppstein [mailto:ceppstein@...]
> Sent: Friday, March 29, 2002 2:48 PM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: RE: [junit] Logging tests reports
>
>
> might want to check out apricot... it's a very interesting
> testing framework
> similar to junit but with more focus on functionality that goes
> beyond your
> basic unit testing.
>
> http://apricot.sourceforge.net/
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Eric Heikkila [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
> Sent: Friday, March 29, 2002 8:42 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Logging tests reports
>
>
> Which is all well and good, *if* you use the
> TextRunner. We currently are using the gui version
> (Swing I think).
>
> But yes, if using TextRunner, that could be a decent
> solution.
>
> -Eric
>
> --- Ilja_Preuß <ilja.preuss@...> wrote:
> > You could simply redirect the output of the
> > TextRunner into a file, so it
> > seems to me.
> >
> > Regards, Ilja
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Eric Heikkila
> > [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
> > Sent: Freitag, 29. März 2002 14:20
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: Re: [junit] Logging tests reports
> >
> >
> > I don't believe it does, but it'd be easy enough
> > to do
> > by throwing in some Log3J code.
> >
> > -Eric
> >
> > --- Luis Joaquim <ljoaquim@...>
> > wrote:
> > > Hello,
> > >
> > > I am just starting to "discover" JUnit, and I
> > have a
> > > begginer's
> > > question:
> > >
> > > Doesn't JUnit keeps the log of executing tests
> > in a
> > > file ?
> > >
> > > Like, how many tests passed, which one failed,
> > ...,
> > > and so on?
> > >
> > > If yes, where ?
> > >
> > > Thanks in advance,
> > >
> > > Luis Joaquim
> > >
> > >
> >
